attributes.action: Introduce a carbon tax
attributes.background: The government should introduce a tax on all commodities and activities that emit carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. For example, there should be a tax on flying by plane etc.
attributes.additional_details: The government should do this to help the fight against climate change. As the price of carbon-emitting activities increase, the consumption of such products should decrease, which should cause more people to shift to renewable energy. This could greatly reduce the carbon footprint of the UK.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Provide additional energy grants for people using machines for palliative care
attributes.background: There are thousands of people who rely on electrical equipment for their palliative care. They need support 24/7. Their bills were high before this year's price hikes and now they are virtually impossible for many patients and their families. More support is needed.
attributes.additional_details: We want the Government to provide additional grants to match the cost of energy used to operate machines that are being used for palliative care.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy
Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Introduce a cap for annual rent increases
attributes.background: The Government should introduce legislation to ensure that private rent cannot be increased beyond a certain rate, so huge increases cannot be levied on tenants. The rate of this cap should be subject to a public consultation.
attributes.additional_details:
I received a 25% price increase on my rent. This means my outgoings on housing are vastly increasing. This is alongside significant increases in energy prices, that make it almost impossible to live on wages that do not rise in line with inflation.
 
Many letting agents have been sending out letters to tenants to advise them on how to shoulder the burden of increased living costs. This would not be necessary if increases in private rent were capped.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Scrap HS2 P1 and use the money to pay for fuel bills (and save the country side)
attributes.background: With the cost of living soaring, we propose scrapping HS2 Phase 1 using the money saved to subsidise energy costs. The obscene devastation that has already been done to the countryside can be left to return to the wild and help the species that are facing extinction.
attributes.additional_details:
It is the sensible thing to do. Concentrate on HS2 Phase 2 to help those in the North with infrastructure there where it is needed.
HS2 Phase 1 is a white elephant.

attributes.action: Nationalise all essential utilities – water, gas and electricity
attributes.background: The Government should take into public ownership the water, gas and electricity companies for the benefit of the people. These companies are making huge profits for their shareholders while people are being forced into poverty through high energy costs.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Cap the cost of car insurance for young drivers.
attributes.background: The Government should impose a cap, like they have on energy prices, to stop insurance companies from charging extortionate prices for young drivers.
attributes.additional_details: Young drivers pay thousands for insurance when driving tests are harder than ever before. Examiners and instructors are being pushed to make better drivers as the government wanted to lower accidents. If the drivers that pass are at a higher standard than previous generations, then why are they paying so much for insurance. A cap is needed to stop insurance companies taking advantage of teenagers and young adults.

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Introduce mandatory carbon footprint ratings for all goods and services
attributes.background: Create requirements, like for nutritional information, that all food, goods and services must display a carbon footprint rating, like the traffic light label on food stuffs, showing the carbon footprint of a good or service. This would help consumers make an informed choice when buying.
attributes.additional_details: We are facing a climate crisis with targets to reduce our carbon emissions. Consumers need information to make informed choices when buying food, goods and services. Government data shows buying a British tomato in winter an have three times the carbon & energy consumption than buying an imported Spanish tomato. There’s lots of examples like this but why stop there on food. It should be compulsory on all goods/services from toilet roll to banking, this will help consumers and promote carbon competition.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Abolish Foreign Aid and use the savings to reduce energy bills
attributes.background: At a time when people are struggling to pay their energy bills, we believe it is only right to put our own people first.
attributes.additional_details: It is time to abolish Foreign Aid and use this budget to support people in Britain who are struggling to pay their energy bills.

departments.name: Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: Remove environmental and social obligation charges for electricity
attributes.background: I would like to see all all environmental and social obligation charges for electricity, which currently account for 25% of the cost of an average electricity bill, to reduce the burden on consumers.
attributes.additional_details: More individuals are struggling to pay their energy bills these charges make it harder to pay energy bills. As a result, people are falling into fuel poverty.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Require new large buildings include renewable energy generation
attributes.background: We want the Government to require new buildings to include renewable power generation, such as solar energy, to ensure that all future commercial and residential building developments accommodating 50 or more people can meet at least 25% of their energy needs for integrated renewable generation.
attributes.additional_details: We want the Government to help us make a cleaner future for all in the UK. Starting by tackling one of the biggest users of fossil fuels; larger residential buildings and workplaces. We want this because in 2020, the UK's fossil fuel dependency was 76.5%. This high consumption of damaging resources puts our future in jeopardy. Introducing a legally bound 25% minimum dependence on integrated renewable energy should reduce reliance on fossil fuels and decrease current over consumption.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Stop the repurposing of allotment sites for the next 3 years during food crisis
attributes.background: Stop the permission of county and town councils from repurposing allotment sites during the food and energy crisis we are seeing nationally. local councils are removing allotment facilities to allow development of housing and other facilities.
attributes.additional_details:
we are seeing an all time high usage of food banks, poverty and debt.
The cost of food is at an all time high, adding to the already expensive energy and transport costs.
Removing the facility of enabling people to grow their own food in these times only adds to the problem were facing nationally.

attributes.action: Abolish police use of Tasers
attributes.background: Police use of Tasers is increasing at a worrying rate. We call for the Government to put an immediate end to police use of Conducted Energy Devices (i.e. Tasers), given their capacity to inflict (sometimes fatal and life-changing) injury.
attributes.additional_details: In England & Wales, police Taser use has increased by more than 500% over the last decade. Since 2003, at least 18 people have died after Tasers were used against them, and many more have sustained serious trauma/injury. Home Office data also reveals that Tasers are used in racially disproportionate ways, and too often used against children and vulnerable adults, particularly those experiencing mental health issues.

departments.name: Home Office

attributes.action: Make it a legal requirement that all new homes have solar energy installed.
attributes.background: I would like the government to introduce a bill to legally bind the construction companies building new houses and flats in the UK , to include with the construction solar panels in the roof. This would help on home running costs and assist in our climate policy pledge on carbon emissions.
attributes.additional_details:
I want the Government to do this as solar panels installed within new homes would be far cheaper than retro fitting after construction. Plus they could be included into the building at the design stage. The homes should be designed with roof direction and slope to maximise energy production.

The bill would be worded with a minimum level of panels per size of home. 

This bill would show that the Government is acting on energy prices.
The Bill would also show we are working towards reducing our carbon emissions and progressing towards our climate change objectives.

It would also show that new homes could be built with energy affordability in mind .

It would  also help in marketing new homes with energy performance  certificates at better levels.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: Set a target for 70% of UK energy to be renewable by 2030
attributes.background: We would like the Government to seek to reduce carbon emissions by considerable amounts by setting a target to increase the UK's renewable energy generation to account for 70% of all energy. By achieving this we hope to reduce pollution and the amount of carbon emissions from the UK.
attributes.additional_details: We would like to stop climate change progressing further than it's currently estimated to rise to in order to save our planet. Fossil fuels are one of the biggest contributors to climate change. Not only that but we rely on fossil fuels to complete everyday tasks. However, fossil fuels will eventually run out so we need a suitable solution to fall back on. To save ourselves and our planet we must make more use of renewable energy sources such as hydro-electric, solar and wind energy.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Invest in coal, oil, gas and nuclear to help achieve energy independence
attributes.background: To help maintain global supply following Russian sanctions but to ensure energy independence medium term, the Government should invest immediately in reopening oil and gas fields in the North Sea and elsewhere, coalfields, and nuclear power plants.
attributes.additional_details:
Whilst we should continue to invest in reducing need for oil and gas we have to accept we are not there yet.

This should help ensure our short and medium term energy independence whilst we continue to invest in sustainable, but independent, alternatives.

Support for nuclear energy would help the whole country be electrically powered through cheap, clean fuel to help ensure a clean and independent future.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Allow energy bills to be paid as part of salary sacrifice, saving Tax & NI
attributes.background: With prices getting incredibly high for electricity bills, we want the Government to enable people to pay energy bills via a salary sacrifice scheme. You can currently lease an electric car, buy a bike, contribute to pension and pay for child care through a salary sacrifice scheme.
attributes.additional_details:
The Government rebate (£350, of which £200 is a loan) is welcome but due to the huge scale of the energy price rises it will help but will still fall well short of helping families through this winter, when the current annual price cap of £1,971 is expected to rise significantly.
 
With salary sacrifice employees have the chance to save huge amounts of tax and national insurance and reduce the level of energy debt they will be in by Feb / March next year. This unfortunately is a decision that cannot wait or be discussed in 6 months time.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Reduce VAT For Hair And Beauty Salons to 5%
attributes.background: We want the Government to reduce VAT for Hair and Beauty Salons to 5%. Hair and Beauty Salons are close contact services that rely on appointments, and are daily being hit by cancellations as a result of covid-19.
attributes.additional_details:
The current rate of VAT, combined with increased costs of energy, staff and goods needed to run salons, is making some businesses unprofitable.
 
Small business like mine are JUST over the threshold could lose their business if VAT is not reduced!
 
The Government should implement a temporary VAT cut for Hair and Beauty Salons, to help them survive through the current situation.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Fund payments to energy customers to cover price rises by taxing oil companies
attributes.background: We demand oil companies cover all or part of the rising fuel costs out of their yearly multi billions of pounds profits, rather than making the consumers pay with energy price increases. Introduce a new tax on these companies to fund a payment to customers to cover the rise in costs.
attributes.additional_details: Stop passing the costs onto the consumers and get the big corporate oil companies to pay, rather than have them enjoying obscene multi billion pound profits at our expense.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Add a 'sustainability charge' on meat products to cover their environmental cost
attributes.background: Food production accounts for one-quarter of the world’s greenhouse gas emissions and takes up half of the planet’s habitable surface. The mass of animals raised for slaughter on Earth now outweighs wildlife by a factor of 15-to-1. One kilogram of beef needs about 15 thousand litres of water.
attributes.additional_details: By adding a 'sustainability charge' to meat products, this will encourage more conscious meat consumption. With this money going towards tackling climate change and renewable energy resources.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Stop energy companies charging more for pre payment meter users.
attributes.background: Prevent energy companies charging more to those on pre payment meters. After all they are being paid up front for the energy instead of in arrears.
attributes.additional_details: Stop energy companies exploitation of people on pre payment meters. Usually these users are the ones lowest paid in society, yet pay more.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ensure all payments for the Fix your Bike Voucher Scheme are made within 17 days
attributes.background: As stated by The Energy Saving Trust, payment for the work done should be as follows: “Downloads of claims will happen weekly by Energy Saving Trust with payment made within 5 working days of download (+ 3 to 5 working days for BACS)”
attributes.additional_details: Hundreds of bike shops have not received payment. The Government should ensure that all bike shops making claims under this scheme receive payment in no more than 17 days (one week to download claims plus 5 working days to issue payment plus 5 working days for BACS).

departments.name: Department for Transport

attributes.action: Create Environmental Impact ratings for businesses with associated fines/reliefs
attributes.background: Implement a simple 5-point rating system similar to hygiene rating, but for all UK businesses and public bodies on their environmental impact, covering all aspects of business supply chain and product life. There would be fines for low performers and financial relief for high performers.
attributes.additional_details:
Implement a 5-point rating system for all businesses in the UK for Environmental Impact. Scoring 1 to 5 similar to hygiene rating. Example would be:
1: High Impact
2: Moderate Impact
3: Mild Impact
4: Minimal or Negligible
5: Beneficial to environment
This would cover suppliers, product life, end of life, transport, energy supply, waste management, impact on environment, dealing with detrimental suppliers. Low scoring businesses will incur fines, and high scoring businesses financial relief.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Impose new taxes on private jets to increase investment in renewables
attributes.background: The aviation industry emits 12% of all transport carbon dioxide emissions. We want the Government to impose new taxes on the use of private jets, to try and reduce CO2 emissions and raise funds to invest in renewable energy, green transportation, and electric vehicle infrastructure.
attributes.additional_details: I believe I can speak on behalf of the planet when I say, we have had enough. We desperately need to reduce the level of carbon emissions entering our atmosphere before we are responsible for the mass extinction of almost 90% of marine species, and the millions of individuals at risk from rising sea levels.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Provide additional funding for swimming pools due to the energy increases
attributes.background: The Government MUST give additional funding to local authorities to ensure swimming pools facing reduced hours or closure due to the current and looming energy increases are able to stay open. Pools require additional energy to keep the pools warm and safe to swim in.
attributes.additional_details: Swimming is an essential life skill, and many schools and home education communities rely on local pools to provide lessons to our children. In addition swimming provides essential health benefits for many people who suffer with chronic pain and restrictive disabilities. Not to mention the health benefits and general well-being that swimming provides to the whole population. Swimming pools MUST remain open and available.

departments.name: Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport

attributes.action: Work internationally to make solar energy the primary energy source
attributes.background:
We believe Climate Change is greatest threat to humanity. An April 2020 Opinion Poll reported 48% of respondents wanted a radical urgent response to it.
 
The UK Government should work with the Commonwealth and members of APEC to make solar energy the world’s primary energy source.
attributes.additional_details:
• The Sun provides 10,000 times more energy than world uses, and is one of the cleanest & most reliable energy sources.
• 43,000 sq miles of solar panels could supply all of the world’s current energy needs.
• Solar panels installed over 3 main areas of Australia/USA/Africa could replace 85% of all fossil fuels by 2030
• We call on the Government to start this urgent action in a joint project with the 18 major CHOGM/APEC members.

Find out more: http://chatasign.com/index.php?action=proposal

departments.name: Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: Withdraw from the Energy Charter Treaty (ECT)
attributes.background: The treaty protects investors in the energy market, including fossil fuel companies. We want the UK to withdraw from this treaty, to ensure it does not restrict our efforts to tackle greenhouse gas emissions.

departments.name: Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office

attributes.action: Change the Energy Profits Levy (EPL) to help UK households and the climate.
attributes.background: The new investment allowance of 91p (for every £1 spent by the oil and gas sector e.g. companies such as BP and Shell) should apply solely to investment in renewable energy projects. The investment allowance for investing in oil and gas extraction should be reduced to 25p for every £1 spent.
attributes.additional_details: The energy sector can make 91p tax saving for every £1 spent on oil and gas extraction in the UK. This was originally 46p. The new tax saving doesn't apply to renewable energy projects. The UK Government expects £5 billion in tax revenue from the EPL. The 5 biggest oil companies shared profits of nearly $100bn in 1st 6 months of 2022. People need help this winter to afford fuel and food. The economy will need further support. £5 billion additional tax revenue from the current EPL isn't enough.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Do not give consent to the Rampion2 windfarm extension off the coast of Sussex
attributes.background: Energy companies should be encouraged to invest in windfarms out of sight of land such as the North Sea, enabling connection with the existing offshore grid network and keeping the impact to a minimum. Here stronger and more consistent winds should result in higher efficiencies than in the Channel.
attributes.additional_details: We believe the proposal to install up to 116 wind turbines in Sussex Bay stretching from Worthing to Selsey will blight the entire horizon along this area of outstanding natural beauty. The turbines will be as tall as 325m, 2.35 times the height of Rampion1 turbines, and higher than any hill in West Sussex. Sited only 8 miles from the shoreline, this proposal will be much nearer land than most offshore windfarms and will impact hard on local communities, the environment and the economy.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Reinstate 5% rate of VAT for the hospitality sector
attributes.background: The whole nation is facing a living cost crisis. Hospitality is already facing increased costs, and has not had a chance to bounce back since Brexit and Covid. We urgently need the return of the 5% VAT rate put in place during the pandemic in order to balance rising costs.
attributes.additional_details: After 25 years working and running community pubs this has been the most challenging two years I have faced. Brexit, Covid and now living costs. Energy prices have increased for me by 20%, others as much as double. Brewers are increasing prices, gas has increased, food and other suppliers too. April rightly sees minimum wage and National Insurance rise as well. All publicans need help now. Things are worse than Covid with the living cost crisis and global instability. Help us survive.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Fund free solar panels for all homes
attributes.background: The Government should fund the installation of solar panels for all existing homes and require solar panels to be installed on all new-build homes within 4 years.
attributes.additional_details:
This would significantly contribute to phasing out the use of fossil fuels and allow the UK to take a global lead in fighting climate change.
 
Combating climate change takes steps, and converting our energy uses and harnessing the best natural renewable energy is one of them.
We are already on our way to switching to electric vehicles, we are opening our eyes to the effect we have on the planet.
Let’s live in a clean, renewable country and take a global lead in combating climate change immediately.
We need to act decisively if we want to preserve our way of life, and to protect the animals that are innocent in all of this.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Withdraw from the Paris agreement related to climate change
attributes.background: The Paris Agreement is a legally binding international treaty on climate change.
attributes.additional_details:
Its goal is to limit global warming to well below 2, preferably to 1.5 degrees Celsius, compared to pre-industrial levels.
 
I am asking the Government to pull out of this agreement.
 
I believe the government has been spending too much money on providing cleaner energy, which is a problem when the national deficit is too high. An example is subsidies to those building wind turbines. I believe this Paris agreement is influencing road taxes for car users as the Government tries to meet its climate goals. Also, businesses may face higher taxes, later on, to pay back the national deficit. I believe that to improve our economy and financial well-being we need to pull out of the Paris agreement.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Add an additional amount to Universal Credit for energy costs
attributes.background:
Just as with other essential living costs, household energy in the form of Gas and Electricity is a basic necessity.
 
Specific additional support for Energy bills should be provided to people on Universal Credit, in the same way as support for housing costs.
attributes.additional_details:
The lowest paid workers & the unemployed receiving Universal Credit receive support for housing costs through Universal Credit. Many claimants are also eligible for Council Tax Support, free prescriptions and free school meals.
 
Household Energy (Gas / Electric) is also a basic essential living cost. Access to warmth and the ability to cook are basic human rights.
 
With the rising costs of Energy bills we need additional financial support through Universal Credit to help the most vulnerable in society.

departments.name: Department for Work and Pensions

attributes.action: Ban drilling for fossil fuels and put more money into using renewable energy.
attributes.background: We see destruction to the environment every day that passes. I believe by banning the drilling on fossil fuels, we can make a difference to what is happening to the Earth right now, alternatively we should use renewable energy and have the government use the technology we have right now.
attributes.additional_details: The banning of drilling for fossil fuels will push more to our goals for the climate, In a few months COP26 will be held in Scotland to discuss the climate crisis; by then it may be more frequent in use meaning more research to improve renewable energy. Thirdly, I believe by doing this other world leaders will follow by example by doing the right thing for the Earth, climate change affects everyone and we need to actually do something longer term rather than short term.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban excess packaging (eg. plastic wrapped items within more plastic, multipacks)
attributes.background: Ban the sale of products using more packaging than is absolutely necessary. This should include multipacks of individually wrapped items. There can always be deals, such as 6 packs of crisps for £1.50, but we do not need excess bags. Excessive boxes within boxes would also be prohibited.
attributes.additional_details: Excess packaging increases bulk rubbish in homes and waste. More fuel energy getting excessively wrapped goods to stores, homes and tips. Prohibiting excess packaging should have little effect on businesses or the buying experience.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Impose new requirements on replacing the Prime Minister and subsequent election
attributes.background: We want the Government to put in place a law that if a Prime Minister indicates an intention to resign, a new Prime Minister must be appointed within 35 days, and a General Election be held within 90 days of the new PM taking office.
attributes.additional_details:
The time it took to replace the last Prime Minister left the country in a leadership vacuum at a critical period of national energy emergency and global economic and security challenges. The Government had a 66-seat majority, yet internal wrangling reduced it to a caretaker administration.
The announcement of a new PM could increase yet another destabilising outcry from opposition parties questioning the PM's legitimacy and mandate.
This law aims to discourage a ruling party from unnecessary changes in leadership at greater cost to the country, and to ensure a future new leader of the ruling party must go to the electorate for a democratic mandate.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Remove VAT from energy-saving products
attributes.background: Remove VAT from energy saving products including insulation, energy-saving lightbulbs, smart heating technology and more. This should encourage households to be more energy efficient as we make the transition in the forthcoming years.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Impose a limit on party donations of £1,000 per individual per party per year
attributes.background:
Impose a limit on donations to political parties to £1000 per person per party per year and restrict party donations to individuals only (no companies or other organisations).
 
If an organisation or individual were to be found breaking this, the funds would be seized by the government.
attributes.additional_details:
There are concerns that Government policy, on issues such as climate change and the escalating energy crisis, is influenced by wealthy individuals and companies that donate to political parties. 
 
Under the system proposed, donations to parties would be limited to individuals, allowing for supporters of a party to still be able to donate but also assuring that the integrity of our democracy is preserved from influence by large donors. This should help ensure that parties serve their voters, and not big donors.

departments.name: Cabinet Office

attributes.action: Reintroduce Feed-in Tariffs for domestic solar panels
attributes.background: Help private households reduce their bills and promote the uptake of renewable energy by reopening the Feed-in Tariffs scheme to new applicants, so households can sell surplus energy back to the grid through a Government scheme.
attributes.additional_details: There are millions of roofs across the country that could be reducing England's carbon footprint and making us less vulnerable to bill increases from energy providers. The Government can help achieve this by reinstating financial incentives for installing renewable technology.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: New planning regulations on all new houses - climate conscious energy supply.
attributes.background:
New planning regulations on all new houses, including self-build, to move towards climate conscious energy supply. All new houses should have:

- Super-Insulation
- Rainwater recovery systems 
- Solar panels
- A wind turbine for larger estates

To come into effect by 2022.
attributes.additional_details: This scheme should contribute to a mass move towards clean energy, in response to the climate crisis, it could also reduce energy costs for the population.

departments.name: Department for Levelling Up, Housing and Communities

attributes.action: All infrastructure projects be tested against the Net Zero Emissions 2050 Law
attributes.background: Ensure that all current and future infrastructure projects as part of Budget 2020 and beyond are rigorously tested against the Net Zero Emissions 2050 law. Sustainable and low carbon projects should then be prioritised including renewable energy and mass public transit.
attributes.additional_details:
The evidence that we are in the midst of a global climate emergency is obvious, the science is obvious. But more than that we can see the impact of climate change every day from floods, to bush fires, Greenland and Antarctica ice melting faster than ever, to the decline in biodiversity. This is not a drill, we need real leadership and we need it now. 

This government speaks about the people's priorities and surely the biggest priority for everyone is a planet that is safe to live on.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Pay full £650 Cost Of Living Payment and £400 energy rebate to everyone directly
attributes.background: The £650 Cost Of Living Payment should be given to everyone equally, no matter their circumstances. The £400 energy rebate should also be given to everyone directly so it can be used to cover other costs, not to the energy providers to then pass on to customers through a reduction in their bills.
attributes.additional_details: Currently, only people on certain benefits or tax credits are eligible for the largest cost of living payment of £650. This should change to help everyone during these hard times.

departments.name: Department for Work and Pensions

attributes.action: Count students as low-income households in Energy Finance Support Package
attributes.background: Given full time students are not entitled to claim means tested welfare benefits unless there are exceptional circumstances, students should count as low-income households to be eligible for more support from the Energy Finance Support Package. The £150 disability segment should go to those on DSA.
attributes.additional_details: According to research from National Student Money Survey 2021 on average students receive £470 a month on maintenance loan. This deficit led to 41% of students to consider dropping out of uni. With the increased energy costs this is set to increase. Students currently work a significant amount of hours on top of full time courses to survive, this energy cost increase will make things worse. For this reason students should be included in the means tested element of energy fund support.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Establish a Royal Commission on Tidal Energy and Coastal Defence
attributes.background: This petition calls for HM Government to establish a Royal Commission to look at integrating coastal defence and tidal power with a Severn Barrage and a network of tidal lagoons; through public-private partnerships. This would also help to level up Wales and the North.
attributes.additional_details:
Tidal power is a simple technology that can be integrated to hydrogen production at slack urban demand, without the risks of nuclear power, and unknown costs regarding clear up and decommissioning.

Tidal power could balance wind generation, with centuries of predictable industrial quantities of power at urban/industrial centres, while modern turbines generate almost continuously.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Raise the level of the Feed In Tariff (FIT) for those with home Solar Panels.
attributes.background: In view of the recent steep rises in the cost of Energy from all Suppliers,  the Government, and Ofgem, should raise the level of the Feed In Tariff (FIT) to make receipts for power uploaded to the Grid from home Solar Panels a fairer reflection of what the Suppliers are now charging users.
attributes.additional_details: Introduced in April 2010, and reduced a number of times since 2012, the FIT requires participating licensed suppliers to make payments on both Generation and Export from eligible installations for those signed up to the scheme before it closed in 2019. These rates were determined and published in the Feed In Tariffs Order 2012 (as amended).  The present 2019 rate being paid now bears no sensible relationship to the cost of power paid by consumers and should be reviewed to reflect this.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Only fund renewable energy projects manufactured in the UK
attributes.background: The Government should only fund UK renewable energy projects that are manufactured in the UK.
attributes.additional_details: The UK heavy engineering and fabrication industry is currently on its knees, we are seeing renewable energy projects/contracts led by overseas companies/consortiums receive public funding while UK yards lie empty and UK jobs suffer. This has to stop. How can an industry be revitalised when the UK Government is providing funding to projects led by overseas companies and consortiums?

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Bring high percentage ethanol fuel to the UK
attributes.background: Follow the lead of European countries including Finland, France and Sweden, also America, Brazil and Australia, incentivise renewable ethanol biofuel to be made available at the fuel pump for the masses.
attributes.additional_details: Ethanol in fuels produce less carbon monoxide due to its more complete combustion and higher oxygen content. Incomplete combustion also creates hydrocarbons. Ethanol also produces less nitrogen oxide emissions which have a huge impact on the environment and humans. Ethanol creates less fine particulate matter which caused an estimated 200,000 premature deaths in 2014. Most engines can convert ethanols energy better and run better. While fuel consumption does go up energy efficiency also goes up.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Require companies to display environmental rating of the products on packaging
attributes.background:
Make it a legal requirement for companies to display environmental impact information of a product on the products packaging in the same way as nutrition information is shown.

The information should include; CO2 emissions and energy used when making the product and proportion of recycled content.
attributes.additional_details:
The nutrition traffic light information provides a consistent measure for consumers allowing them to compare one product to another.
 
The intention is that a similar approach can be used for environmental impact information helping consumers make an informed decision as to which is better for the environment and therefore which to buy.
 
This in turn will drive competition between producers in this area incentivising them to look for ways to improve the products environmental credentials.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Lower fuel duty tax based on the mixture of renewable matter in it
attributes.background: Fuel duty tax currently stands at £0.5795 per litre on petrol fuel. The Government should change this rate relative to the bio-ethanol content of the fuel (currently around 5%). This would reduce the cost of fuels that produce less CO2, and should make these fuels more affordable to motorists.
attributes.additional_details:
Creating financial incentives to increase the bio-ethanol content of fuel should decrease the amount of petroleum based fuels burnt in cars in the UK and so decrease the national net CO2 output.
 
This change should not decrease tax revenue as ethanol contains less energy per litre of fuel than petrol, so although it would be cheaper to buy, a greater volume must be used to travel the same distance in a car.

departments.name: HM Treasury

attributes.action: Increase subsidies and grants for homeowners to improve their energy ratings
attributes.background: We're asking for an increase in subsidies and grants available to improve domestic energy ratings and reduce their emissions. This can be done through providing money for solar panels, heat pumps, improved insulation etc.
attributes.additional_details:
22% of the UK’s carbon emissions come from our homes, with ¾ of this from our heating. We must make it easier for people to make their houses more eco-friendly, without them having to spend absurd amounts of money. For example, the costs of installing solar panels alone costs an average of around £6,000, making improvements like this unavailable for 20 million UK households. 

More must be done to combat this issue, otherwise we have no chance of meeting our net zero target.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Make it compulsory for schools and workplaces to have recycling bins
attributes.background: Recycling saves energy as it reduces the need for extracting, refining and processing materials all of which create air & water pollution, and greenhouse gas emissions. Recycling can help tackle climate change, and schools and workplaces should be required to have recycling bins to help with this.
attributes.additional_details: Additionally, recycling is a diverse industry and when compared to waste disposal it is much more labour intensive. This means building the recycling industry is also a way to create more jobs. It is said that disposing of 10,000 tons of waste in a landfill creates six jobs, as opposed to recycling the same amount of waste, which creates 36 jobs. Overall, there are many benefits to be derived from recycling and schools and workplaces should be required to contribute to recycling.
